docs.snippet: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 -- Secret new drugs against malaria, described as "an enemy more dangerous than the Japanese," are now being tested in the field, with results expected to bring about "improvements of inestimable value in the therapy of...
docs.lead_paragraph: PHILADELPHIA, Oct. 22 -- Secret new drugs against malaria, described as "an enemy more dangerous than the Japanese," are now being tested in the field, with results expected to bring about "improvements of inestimable value in the therapy of malaria."

headline.main: MALARIA IS FOUGHT WITH SECRET DRUGS; Advance in Conquest Forecast to Military Surgeons in Use of New Remedies in Pacific AIR AMBULANCES HAILED 90-Patient Craft to Fly Soon, Load of 400 Later -- Doctors Face Draft Up to Age of 45

docs.snippet: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Oct 23 (UP) -- Reports from Buenos Aires tonight said the Argentine situation was tense, with some 40,000 students boycotting universities throughout the country and a general labor strike threatened as a protest against the...
docs.lead_paragraph: MONTEVIDEO, Uruguay, Oct 23 (UP) -- Reports from Buenos Aires tonight said the Argentine situation was tense, with some 40,000 students boycotting universities throughout the country and a general labor strike threatened as a protest against the attitude of the Ramirez government.

docs.snippet: Improvement in the Canadian free dollar was carried further last week. It sold at 90 cents on several days, from 89 cents made on Monday, and at this peak showed a gross recovery of 2 7/16 cents from the low made about ten days ago. At the closing...
docs.lead_paragraph: Improvement in the Canadian free dollar was carried further last week. It sold at 90 cents on several days, from 89 cents made on Monday, and at this peak showed a gross recovery of 2 7/16 cents from the low made about ten days ago. At the closing price of 89.75 cents, the free dollar was 7/8 cent above the final price of the preceding week.

headline.main: FOREIGN EXCHANGE RATES; WEEK ENDED OCT. 23, 1943

docs.snippet: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- A recommendation that publishers of magazines and periodicals be subjected to a further cut of 15 per cent in paper tonnage beginning Jan. 1, has been submitted to the War Production Board by the industry's advisory committee.
docs.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Oct. 27 -- A recommendation that publishers of magazines and periodicals be subjected to a further cut of 15 per cent in paper tonnage beginning Jan. 1, has been submitted to the War Production Board by the industry's advisory committee.

headline.main: TRADE ASKS CURB ON MAGAZINE PAPER; Additional 15% Cut Suggested by Industry Committee -- Other War Agency Action
